title: Is Power Training Effective to Produce Muscle Hypertrophy in Older Adults? A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
authors: Bet da Rosa Orssatto L; Bezerra E; Shield A; Trajano GS

sections.abstract:
17 
Power training has been suggested to be effective to improve st rength, power, and functional 18 
capacity in older adults. However, there is still a lack of systematic investigations reporting its 19 
effectiveness for muscle hypertrophy. Thus, this study investigated the effect of power training 20 
on muscle hypertrophy and compared its magnitude with tradition al moderate-velocity 21 
resistance training in older adults. A systematic search was conducted to identify clinical trials 22 
investigating the effect of power training on muscle hypertroph y (power training vs. control), 23 
and/or comparing the effect of power training vs. moderate-velo city resistance training for a 24 
meta-analytical approach. Ten studies comparing power training to control conditions and nine 25 
studies comparing power training to moderate-velocity resistance training were selected. Three 26 
studies were classified as high quality and two were preregiste red. The meta-analysis showed 27 
that power training was superior for muscle hypertrophy compare d to control condition (n=8 28 
studies; SMD=0.31; 95%CI=0.04, 0.58; p=0.029), and resulted in similar hypertrophy 29 
compared to moderate-velocity resistance training (n=7 studies; SMD=0.07; 95%CI=-0.18, 30 
0.32; p=0.50). No significant heterogeneity was observed (p=0.46 and 0.54, and I2=0 and 0%, 31 
respectively). Our data suggest that power training is effective for muscle hypertrophy in older 32 
adults, with similar effectiveness as moderate-velocity resistance training. 33 
Novelty 34 
-It is known that power training might be superior to moderate-velocity resistance training for 35 
function improvements in older adults, but there was no meta-an alysis investigating its effect 36 
on muscle hypertrophy. 37 
-Power training is effective to induce muscle hypertrophy in older adults to a similar extent to 38 
moderate-velocity resistance training. 39 
Key words: Ageing; Elderly; Hypertrophy; Strength training; Resistance tra ining. 40 
PROSPERO registration number: CRD42019128951 41 

3 
 
1.
sections.introduction:
42 
The number of humans above 65 years of age is expected to reach approximately 1.6 43 
billion globally, by the year of 2050. The expectation that older adults remain actively engaged 44 
in the work-force for longer, and the socioeconomic burden impo sed by their loss of 45 
independence (Stevens et al. 2006; Burge et al. 2007; Heinrich et al. 2010; Cross et al. 2014; 46 
Hunter et al. 2014; Bruyère et al. 2019) makes the development of effective strategies to 47 
attenuate the negative effects of aging increasingly important. Aging is accompanied by a 48 
remarkable reduction in muscle mass, which accelerate after 60 years (Janssen et al. 2000; Kyle 49 
et al. 2001; Orssatto et al. 2018; Larsson et al. 2019). Theref ore, it seems imperative to 50 
determine what strategies are optimal (or sub-optimal) to promote muscle hypertrophy in older 51 
adults. 52 
Resistance training is considered the gold-standard treatment t o increase or maintain 53 
muscle mass and counteract the age-related muscle wastage (Steib et al. 2010a; Peterson et al. 54 
2011; Borde et al. 2015; Csapo and Alegre 2015; Lopez et al. 20 18; Orssatto et al. 2018; 55 
Beckwée et al. 2019). Resistance training is typically performed with moderate velocities (2-3 56 
s) in older adults (Borde et al. 2015), but recently, it has been suggested that training with high-57 
velocity movements (i.e. power training) would provide superior benefits for this population 58 
(Byrne et al. 2016; Cadore and Izquierdo 2018; Cadore et al. 20 18; Orssatto et al. 2019a, 59 
2019b). Power training may elicits greater improvements in func tional capacity and muscular 60 
power (Steib et al. 2010a; Straight et al. 2015; Byrne et al. 2016; Orssatto et al. 2019a, 2019b) 61 
and can improve muscular strength to a similar extent to that observed after slow to moderate-62 
velocity resistance training (Steib et al. 2010a; Tschopp et al . 2011; Byrne et al. 2016). 63 
However, the effects on muscle are contradictory, where some original studies reported muscle 64 
hypertrophy (Henwood et al. 2008; Correa et al. 2012; Cadore et al. 2014) while others did not 65 
(Marsh et al. 2009; Wallerstein et al. 2012; Zech et al. 2012). It has been recommended that 66 

4 
 
power training should be employed with lower intensity (40-60% and 70-85% of 1RM, 67 
respectively) and number of repetitions compared to traditional resistance training (Fragala et 68 
al. 2019; Orssatto et al. 2019b), resulting in lower training volume. It is important to note that 69 
training volume is probably the most important training variabl e to promote muscle 70 
hypertrophy (Figueiredo et al. 2017). In addition, this populat ion presents a lower anabolic 71 
response to resistance training (i.e. anabolic resistance) when compared to young adults 72 
(Hodson et al. 2019). Thus it is not clear if, the typically lo w volume, power training is an 73 
enough stimulus to induce significant muscle hypertrophy in old er adults. If so, it is also not 74 
known if it is as effective as the traditional moderate-velocity resistance training, since higher 75 
training volumes (typically observed during moderate-velocity resistance training) are required 76 
to enhance muscle hypertrophy in older adults (Peterson et al. 2011; Figueiredo et al. 2017). 77 
There is a lack of high-quality systematic review comparing the effect of these two 78 
training modalities on muscle hypertrophy. In fact, only two st udies have attempted to 79 
synthesise the literature on this topic. One was a narrative re view that did not involve a meta-80 
analysis (Orssatto et al. 2019a). The other was a systematic review and meta-analysis (Tschopp 81 
et al. 2011), however, the literature search was conducted 9 ye ars ago and only two studies 82 
comparing both types of training were included. In regards to this last study, it is important to 83 
note two major limitations, which are the low statistical power , and the lack of risk of bias 84 
assessment. As a number of experimental trials have been publis hed since the most recent 85 
systematic review, it is now possible to conduct a meta-analysi s providing more robust 86 
evidence about the topic. This study aims to investigate the effect of power training on muscle 87 
hypertrophy in older adults. Thereafter, we aim to compare the effect of power versus 88 
moderate-velocity resistance training on muscle hypertrophy in older adults. It was 89 
hypothesised that power training does result in muscle hypertro phy and that this effect would 90 
be of similar magnitude to that observed after moderate-velocity resistance training. 91 

5 
 
2.
sections.methods:
92 
This study was registered at the International Prospective Regi ster of Systematic 93 
Reviews (PROSPERO: CRD42019128951). The conduct and reporting of this review followed 94 
the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-A nalyses (PRISMA) 95 
guidelines (Moher et al. 2009) and was designed based on criteria from A MeaSurement Tool 96 
to Assess systematic Reviews (AMSTAR) (Pollock et al. 2017). 97 
 98 
2.1. Search strategy and eligibility criteria 99 
A systematic literature search was undertaken in the PUBMED, SCOPUS, and Web of 100 
Science databases in May 2019. The adopted terms were related to aging, power and resistance 101 
training, and muscle mass. The complete search strategy adopted for each database is detailed 102 
in Supplemental File 1. After study selection, the reference li sts of selected studies were 103 
screened for additional studies. The search included journal ar ticles, conference proceeding 104 
and meeting abstracts, with no language restriction. Two different study selection criteria were 105 
used: 1) Studies in which power training was compared to a cont rol condition; and 2) Studies 106 
in which power training was compared to moderate-velocity resistance training. The PRISMA 107 
flow diagram is illustrated in Figure 1 (Moher et al. 2009). 108 
Study inclusion was decided by the consensus between authors LB RO and ESB. In 109 
cases of disagreement on the inclusion of an article, GST was consulted. Inclusion criteria were 110 
defined according to the PICOS approach (Liberati et al. 2009). Study selection criteria 1: 111 
Population: participants aged ≥60 years; Intervention: resistan ce training-based intervention; 112 
Comparator: Power training compared to control conditions; Outc ome: changes in muscle or 113 
lean mass after the intervention; Study design: randomised cont rolled trials. Study selection 114 
criteria 2: Adopted a similar approach compared to the selectio n c r i t e r i a 1 , e x c e p t f o r t h e 115 

6 
 
comparator considering the training velocity comparison (power training vs. moderate-velocity 116 
resistance training) and the study design (randomised trials). 117 
Exclusion criteria were defined as follows: 1) did not compare the effects of power 118 
training (fast concentric velocity) with a control group and/or a moderate-velocity resistance 119 
training group (where moderate-velocity training was characterised by concentric contractions 120 
lasting ≥ 2 s); 2) did not report
sections.results:
adequately without accessibility to the data by alternative 121 
manners (e.g., contacting authors); 3) examination of the effects of combined training methods 122 
(i.e. power and moderate-velocity resistance training) within t he same group (e.g., mixed 123 
session periodization (Bezerra et al. 2018)); 4) Adopted a doub ly indirect body composition 124 
method (e.g., anthropometric or bioelectrical impedance measure ments). In addition, when 125 
different published reports were d erived from the same trial, w e excluded the one with the 126 
shorter intervention period. 127 
 128 
2.2. Data extraction 129 
First, study characteristics were extracted: Country where the study was conducted, 130 
participants’ age, baseline and final sample size (n), muscle h ypertrophy assessment method 131 
and the measured body part. Thereafter, training characteristic s were extracted: Adopted 132 
exercises, training duration, weekly frequency, intensity, sets and repetition volume, rest 133 
interval and contraction velocities. 134 
For the meta-analysis, the mean and standard deviation (or stan dard error) of the 135 
outcome measurements (muscle or lean mass) were extracted for e ach group. When data was 136 
presented in graphs, data was extracted with Web Plot Digitizer (version 4.1). When the 137 
standard error was reported, it was transformed in standard dev iation by multiplying the 138 
standard error by the square root of the sample size. 139 
 140 

7 
 
2.3. Quality assessment 141 
Methodological study quality was carried out using the Physioth erapy Evidence 142 
Database (PEDro) scale (Maher et al. 2003). This scale rates ra ndomised clinical trials on a 143 
scale from 0 to 10 (low- to high-quality) with a cut-off score for high-quality of 6 points. With 144 
the intention of avoiding potential author’s bias, scores were obtained from PEDro database, 145 
in which the studies are scored by independent researches. When a study was not available on 146 
the PEDro database, LBRO and ESB independently rated the risk o f bias. Any disagreement 147 
was resolved by GST. In addition, articles were screened to identify if prospective registration 148 
of the clinical trial was conducted. 149 
 150 
2.4. Statistical analysis 151 
Muscle hypertrophy were calculated for control, power training and moderate-velocity 152 
resistance training groups from the difference between final an d baseline mean and standard 153 
deviation. For the studies in which change standard deviation was not reported, it was imputed 154 
with a specific equation (r = 0.5) (Higgins and Green 2008). 155 
RStudio (Version 1.0.153) was used for all analyses (packages: meta (Balduzzi et al. 156 
2019), metafor (Viechtbauer 2010), dmetar (Harrer et al. 2019), dplyr, and tidyverse (Wickham 157 
et al. 2019)). Meta-analysis was undertaken with the standardised mean difference, the inverse 158 
variance method, random effects (Hartung-Knapp adjustment), with Sidik-Jonkman estimator 159 
for τ2 (Sidik and Jonkman 2007). Heterogeneity was assessed by visual inspection of forest 160 
plots and using X2 test for heterogeneity (α = 10%), and described inconsistency between trials 161 
using the I2 statistic (I2 = 0 – 40%, might not be important; 30 – 60%, may represent moderate 162 
heterogeneity; 50 – 90%, may represent substantial heterogeneity; and 75 – 100%, considerable 163 
heterogeneity) (Deeks et al. 2008). Two meta-analyses were cond ucted: 1) comparing power 164 

8 
 
training and control groups; and 2) comparing power training and moderate-velocity resistance 165 
training groups. 166 
When studies compared the control group with two power training groups (Correa et 167 
al. 2012; Strandberg et al. 2015), the standardised mean difference was pooled before the final 168 
meta-analysis. The same was performed when a study presented mu ltiple measures of muscle 169 
hypertrophy. These results were pooled with the inverse varianc e and random effects method 170 
(Higgins and Green 2008). We adopted α = 5% for all meta-analysis. 171 

9 
 
3. RESULTS 172 
3.1.Summary of findings 173 
The systematic search retrieved 1749 studies, 609 of which were duplicates. 1140 titles 174 
and abstracts and 85 full-text were screened for eligibility. T he selection of manuscripts 175 
comparing power training and control conditions resulted in ten included studies (Reid et al. 176 
2008; Henwood et al. 2008; Marsh et al. 2009; Correa et al. 2012; Wallerstein et al. 2012; Zech 177 
et al. 2012; Cadore et al. 2014; Strandberg et al. 2015; Hvid et al. 2016; Gray et al. 2018), and 178 
the selection of manuscripts comparing power training and moder ate-velocity resistance 179 
training resulted in nine included studies (Reid et al. 2008; H enwood et al. 2008; Marsh et al. 180 
2009; Nogueira et al. 2009; Claflin et al. 2011; Correa et al. 2012; Wallerstein et al. 2012; Zech 181 
et al. 2012; Gray et al. 2018). A PRISMA flow diagram of the ar ticles search, included, and 182 
excluded studies are described in Figure 1. A list of excluded studies is presented in 183 
Supplemental File 2. 184 
 185 
** Figure 1 near here ** 186 
 187 
3.2.Methodological Quality 188 
PEDro scores ranged from 3 to 7 for the selected studies, with only three studies ranked 189 
as high-quality (Reid et al. 2008; Zech et al. 2012; Cadore et al. 2014) (Table 1 and 190 
Supplemental File 3). The low overall rating resulted mainly fr om the lack of allocation 191 
concealment, participant, therapist, and assessor blinding, adequate follow-up, and the lack of 192 
intention-to-treat analysis for most of the studies (Supplement al File 3 provided a detailed 193 
description for each study). From the selected studies, only tw o pre-registered their clinical 194 
trials (Zech et al. 2012; Hvid et al. 2016) (Table 1). 195 
 196 

10 
 
3.3.Studies characteristics 197 
Ten studies were included in the power training vs. control com parison with a total of 198 
257 and 200 participants at the commencement of training and co ntrol interventions, 199 
respectively. However, 195 of 257 experimental and 149 of 200 control participants completed 200 
the studies and were included in the analyses; giving dropout r ates of ~25% and ~27%, for 201 
power training and control groups, respectively. Regarding the muscle/lean mass assessment 202 
methods, the studies used computed tomography (n = 1), magnetic resonance imaging (n = 1), 203 
ultrasonography (n = 2), and dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry ( n = 6). Six studies assessed 204 
lower limbs and four assessed the whole body (Table 1). 205 
Nine studies were included in the power training vs. moderate-v elocity resistance 206 
training comparison. A total of 193 and 184 participants starte d the power training and 207 
moderate-velocity training interventions, respectively, while 1 57 and 136 concluded the final 208 
measurements and were included in the analyses, with dropout ra tes of ~22% and ~25% for 209 
power training and moderate-velocity training, respectively. Th e studies used magnetic 210 
resonance imaging (n = 1), muscle fibre biopsy (n = 1), ultraso nography (n = 2), and dual-211 
energy x-ray absorptiometry (n = 5). Five of them assessed lowe r limbs, one the upper limbs, 212 
and four the whole body (Table 1). 213 
Participants’ age means ranged from 63.0 to 93.4 years, eight s tudies included 214 
apparently health and active elderly and four studies included institutionalised frail, mobility-215 
limited, or pre-frail elderly. All studies reported that included participants were untrained. One 216 
study tested only men, two tested only women, two did not report the participants’ sex, and the 217 
other studies mixed men and women. 218 
 219 
** Table 1 near here ** 220 
 221 

11 
 
3.4.Training Characteristics 222 
The training characteristics varied among studies. Training duration ranged from 10 to 223 
48 weeks and training session frequency ranged from 2 to 3 sessions per week and these were 224 
similar between power and moderate-velocity resistance training for all the studies. On the 225 
other hand, training intensity for power training ranged from 3 0 to 85% and for moderate-226 
velocity resistance training from 40 to 85% of 1RM. The intensity was similar between groups 227 
in four studies and lower for power training in three studies c ompared to moderate-velocity 228 
resistance training. The number of sets (2-4) and repetition range (4-15) were similar between 229 
power and moderate-velocity resistance training groups, except in one study (Wallerstein et al. 230 
2012) (Table 2). 231 
 232 
** Table 2 near here ** 233 
 234 
3.5.The effect of power training vs. control condition on muscle hypertrophy 235 
The meta-analysis comparing power training to a control conditi on included eight 236 
studies because it was not possible to access the data from Rei d et al. (2008) and Gray et al. 237 
(2018). Meta-analysis indicated that power training had a positive effect on muscle hypertrophy 238 
compared to the control condition (p = 0.0296). There was no he terogeneity between studies 239 
(X2 statistics, p = 0.457) (Figure 2). 240 
 241 
** Figure 2 here ** 242 
 243 

12 
 
3.6. Power training vs. Moderate-velocity resistance training and muscle 244 
hypertrophy 245 
The meta-analysis comparing power training to moderate-velocity resistance training 246 
included seven studies because it was not possible to access th e data from Reid et al. (2008) 247 
and Gray et al. (2018). Meta-analysis indicated similar effects for muscle hypertrophy between 248 
groups (p = 0.499). There was no significant heterogeneity in t hese results (X2 statistics, p = 249 
0.536) (Figure 3). 250 
** Figure 3 here ** 251 

13 
 
4.
sections.discussion:
252 
 253 
4.1. Effects of power training on muscle hypertrophy 254 
The main findings of the present systematic review and meta-ana lysis indicate a 255 
positive effect of power training on muscle hypertrophy when compared to control conditions. 256 
When comparing the effects of power training vs. moderate-veloc ity resistance training, the 257 
meta-analysis resulted in a standardised mean difference almost equal to zero, which suggests 258 
similar muscle hypertrophy when training with either method. 259 
The comparison between power training and control conditions de monstrated a 260 
significant effect favouring power training. However, it could be noted that for three studies 261 
the effect was null, two studies presented a very small effect, and three studies resulted in an 262 
advantage for power training with effect higher than the pooled standardised mean difference. 263 
This varied response is also reflected in the 95% predictive in terval, which shows that it is 264 
expected in future study effects ranging from -0.28 to 0.89. It was not possible to find any 265 
determinant factor to speculate the reasons for the observed differences in effects. For example, 266 
participants’ characteristics (age and health status) and muscl e hypertrophy measurement 267 
methods varied similarly between the studies with small and lar g e e ff e c t ( Se e T a b l e 1 a n d 268 
Figure 2). The same is observed for the power training characte r i s t i c s , w h e r e s t u d i e s w i t h 269 
smaller and larger effects varied similarly for exercise quanti ty, training duration, frequency, 270 
intensity, sets per exercise, repetitions per set, and between-sets rest interval (See Table 2 and 271 
Figure 2). Therefore, these results might have been influenced by the small number of studies 272 
and the heterogeneity observed for participants, training chara cteristics, and hypertrophy 273 
measurement sites and methods (Tables 1 and 2). However, it doe s not allow any speculation 274 
trying to understand the differences between-studies magnitude of effect differences when 275 
compared to control conditions. 276 

14 
 
There was a similar effect observed for the comparison between power and moderate-277 
velocity resistance training. Of the seven studies included, tw o showed an advantage for 278 
moderate-velocity resistance training (Henwood et al. 2008; Wallerstein et al. 2012), while two 279 
showed an advantage for power training (Nogueira et al. 2009; C orrea et al. 2012). 280 
Interestingly, the studies favouring moderate-velocity resistan ce training adopted lower 281 
volume-load (i.e., lower % of 1RM for both studies and less rep etitions were used in 282 
Wallerstein et al. (2012)) for the power training groups, while studies favouring power training 283 
employed similar volume-load between groups (Nogueira et al. 2009; Correa et al. 2012). It is 284 
important to note that the two studies that reported favourable results for power training lasted 285 
six (Correa et al. 2012) and 10 weeks (Nogueira et al. 2009), w hile the two studies favouring 286 
moderate-velocity resistance training were 16 (Wallerstein et al. 2012) and 22 (Henwood et al. 287 
2008) weeks in duration. Thus, it is unclear if power training induces a faster muscle 288 
hypertrophy response and moderate-velocity resistance training a higher response after longer 289 
periods, or if it is just because the total training volume-load (Figueiredo et al. 2017) was lower 290 
for power training in these studies favouring moderate-velocity . Other training variables 291 
(exercise selection, duration, frequency, sets per exercise, re ps per set, and between-sets 292 
interval) were matched between power training and moderate-velo city resistance training for 293 
most of the studies, which allows us to speculate that simply increasing the contraction velocity 294 
did not reduce the magnitude of muscle hypertrophy when compared to moderate velocity. As 295 
mentioned for the power training vs control conditions comparison, the small number of studies 296 
and the heterogeneity observed for participants, training chara cteristics, and hypertrophy 297 
measurement sites and methods (Tables 1 and 2) might have influ enced the results. However, 298 
all this heterogeneity makes it difficult the understanding of the reasons or mechanisms related 299 
to the between-studies dissimilar responses. 300 
 301 

15 
 
4.2. Agreement and disagreement with other reviews 302 
To the best of the authors’ knowledge, no previous meta-analysi s has investigated the 303 
effects of power training, compared to a control group, on muscle hypertrophy in older adults. 304 
Borde et al. (2015) reported a standardised mean difference of 0.42 (95% CI = 0.18 – 0.66) 305 
comparing resistance training with a control group in older adu lts, which is similar to our 306 
results for power training. 307 
Two previous reviews attempted to compare the effects of power and moderate-velocity 308 
resistance training on muscle hypertrophy in older adults (Tsch opp et al. 2011; Orssatto et al. 309 
2019a). Tschopp et al. (2011) reported similar muscle hypertrophy between moderate-velocity 310 
resistance training and power training. However, their meta-analysis included only two studies 311 
(Marsh et al. 2009; Nogueira et al. 2009). Orssatto et al. (2019a) reported a similar percentage 312 
change per week with these two training methods; although, they did not conduct a systematic 313 
review and meta-analysis to compare training methods. Despite these limitations, these reviews 314 
are in agreement with our findings. 315 
 316 
4.3. Potential biases in the review process and data analyses 317 
The systematic literature search resulted in ten studies compar ing the effects of power 318 
training to control condition, and nine studies comparing power and moderate-velocity 319 
resistance training methods. Eight studies were included in the power training vs. control 320 
comparison, and seven in the power training versus moderate-velocity resistance training meta-321 
analyses. 322 
We tried to reduce bias during data analyses by excluding diffe rent articles from the 323 
same clinical trial, thereby avoiding results duplication (Higgins and Green 2008). Strandberg 324 
et al. (2015) published a second study from the same clinical t rial two years later (Edholm et 325 
al. 2017). Zech et al. (2012) performed a clinical trial with a duration of 36 weeks but also 326 

16 
 
published data from the first 12 weeks of their study (Drey et al. 2012). Unfortunately, Reid et 327 
al. (2008) and Gray et al. (2018) did not report the complete body composition data and did not 328 
respond to our request for data so these studies could not be included in the meta-analyses. 329 
We also attempted to minimise bias by selecting only studies that did not adopt doubly 330 
indirect body composition measurements. However, some limitatio ns regarding the different 331 
muscle assessment methods should be mentioned. Magnetic resonance imaging and computed 332 
tomography measured the cross-sectional area of the selected mu scles, while ultrasound was 333 
used to measure the muscle thickness (distance from the most superficial to the deepest muscle 334 
aponeurosis on a cross-sectional section), and dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry measured total 335 
body or appendicular lean mass, which contains other tissues different from fat. Thus, different 336 
methods might result in different magnitude of changes (Vigotsk y et al. 2018; Haun et al. 337 
2019). However, this bias is minimised because between-group co mparisons (power training 338 
vs. control and power vs. moderate-velocity resistance training ) always involved a single 339 
method of measurement, and studies effects sizes were pooled wi th a standardised mean 340 
difference. 341 
 342 
4.4.Heterogeneity, publication bias, quality of the evidence, and pre-registration 343 
No significant heterogeneity was observed for either meta-analy ses, which indicate 344 
homogeneity of study results. The small number of studies inclu ded in the meta-analysis 345 
disallowed assessment of small-studies publication bias with a funnel plot and Egger’s test 346 
analysis, which requires >10 studies for enough statistical power to distinguish real asymmetry 347 
(Higgins and Green 2008). 348 
 Our results might be influenced by a high risk of bias, derived from their 349 
methodological quality because only two studies (Zech et al. 20 12) included in the current 350 
meta-analyses achieved a high-quality classification according to the PEDro scale (≥ 6 points). 351 

17 
 
Future studies should attempt to address some feasible criteria not addressed in most of the 352 
included studies, such as concealed allocation, blinding of ass essors, and intention-to-treat 353 
analysis. Moreover, only two studies conducted a prospective registration of their clinical trials 354 
(Zech et al. 2012; Hvid et al. 2016). It has been suggested tha t pre-registration can increase 355 
research transparency by reporti ng all the methods, procedures, and outcomes before the 356 
intervention commencement, avoiding selective reporting of outc omes and manipulation of 357 
statistical analysis favouring significant effects (Zarin et al. 2011; Kaplan and Irvin 2015). 358 
 359 
4.5. Relevance of muscle hypertrophy for older adults 360 
The loss of muscle mass during aging is detrimental for older a dults’ health. For 361 
example, skeletal muscle plays a role in determining insulin re sistance (Matta et al. 2016), 362 
cardiovascular disease (Baumgartner et al. 1999), arterial stif fness (Ochi et al. 2010), bone 363 
mineral content (Baumgartner et al. 1996), and in the secretion of myokines (e.g., growth 364 
factors and cytokines), which can affect the age-related deteri oration of several others 365 
biological systems (Demontis et al. 2013). Higher levels of mus cle loss combined with 366 
decreases in muscle strength and functional capacity can lead to sarcopenia (Cruz-Jentoft et al. 367 
2019). Thus, benefit of muscle hypertrophy induced by using the power training method, which 368 
might be more effective than moderate-velocity resistance training for other training outcomes, 369 
has an important implication for older adults’ health. It has b een shown that power training 370 
favours power and explosive force adaptations (Steib et al. 201 0b; Straight et al. 2015; Byrne 371 
et al. 2016; Orssatto et al. 2019a). However, the potential adv antage for functional capacity 372 
improvements remains unclear (Orssatto et al. 2019b). 373 
 374 
 375 
 376 

18 
 
4.6. Implications for research 377 
Most of the studies included in our meta-analysis were of low m ethodological quality 378 
and only two were pre-registered. Further high quality, pre-reg istered trials are required to 379 
conclusively evaluate the relative effectiveness of power train ing for muscle hypertrophy in 380 
older adults. In addition, the use of similar intensities betwe en groups should be considered 381 
because this is a potentially confounding factor when comparing power and moderate-velocity 382 
resistance training. Future studies should also consider the us e of more robust and accurate 383 
methods of assessing muscle volume (e.g., magnetic resonance im aging, computed 384 
tomography or ultrasound) rather than muscle thickness, anatomi cal cross-sectional area, and 385 
lean mass assessment. 386 
Researchers should also consider the typical ~25% dropout rates observed in studies of 387 
this type when determining participant numbers. This may help t o ensure adequate statistical 388 
power for the final statistical analyses. 389 

19 
 
5.
sections.conclusions:
390 
Based on the available data, our findings suggest that power tr aining is as effective as 391 
moderate-velocity resistance training for muscle hypertrophy in older persons. However, the 392 
lack of high-quality and pre-registered studies and the lack of more accurate methods use for 393 
muscle hypertrophy assessment indicates the need to adopt more robust methods in future 394 
studies. Nevertheless, the current evidence indicates that powe r training can be prescribed to 395 
muscle hypertrophy in older adults. Caution should be taken when extrapolating these findings 396 
for trained individuals. 397 

20 
 
6. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE 398 
 Our findings have significant implications for clinical practic e. Exercise professionals 399 
may consider both the use of power training or moderate-velocit y resistance training 400 
for muscle hypertrophy in untrained older persons. 401 
 Based on the evidence available to date this type of training c ould be preferred over 402 
moderate-velocity resistance training since our data showed sim ilar muscle 403 
hypertrophy between methods, and previous studies indicated that power training might 404 
be superior for functional capacity and power (Steib et al. 201 0a; Straight et al. 2015; 405 
Byrne et al. 2016; Orssatto et al. 2019a) improvements in older adults. It is important 406 
to highlight that all studies adopted untrained participants, which does not allow certain 407 
extrapolation of our findings for resistance-trained participants. 408 
 The wide heterogeneity observed between studies’ training proto cols should be 409 
considered when prescribing power training for older adults. 410 
 It is important to consider, however, that the interventions included in the current study 411 
were 6-24 weeks in duration, so it is not possible to determine how power training 412 
compares to moderate-velocity training over longer periods. 413 

21
